subs.text: August 1

Bloody hell why can't things just work
Just spent last 20 minutes getting my sound working again
It broke after I touched precisely NOTHING

Grrrrrr

subs.text:
JT: Most sustainable, archivable: static websites (HTML, CSS, JavaScript, minimal dependencies)
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: Most sustainable, archivable: static websites (HTML, CSS, JavaScript, minimal dependencies)
#balisage2022

subs.text:
JT: Problem: How to add search to static websites?
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: Problem: How to add search to static websites?
#balisage2022

subs.text:
JT: Client side libraries? Have to be in memory; doesn't scale to large websites. Google? elasticsearch? Other issues. Decided to build our own: staticSearch, client side website search
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: Client side libraries? Have to be in memory; doesn't scale to large websites. Google? elasticsearch? Other issues. Decided to build our own: staticSearch, client side website search
#balisage2022

subs.text:
JT: staticSearch XSLT/Ant process to generated inverted index of JSON files

Has stemming in multiple languages, wildcards, exact phrases, boolean, configurable filters, contextual...

Every search is bookmarkable URL

#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: staticSearch XSLT/Ant process to generated inverted index of JSON files

Has stemming in multiple languages, wildcards, exact phrases, boolean, configurable filters, contextual...

Every search is bookmarkable URL

#balisage2022

subs.text:
JT: 
Input: collection of WF HTML5 in XHTML namespace
Plus: configuration file
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: 
Input: collection of WF HTML5 in XHTML namespace
Plus: configuration file
#balisage2022

subs.text:
JT: rules tell you what to exclude (default is index everything), contexts to give labels (use match patterns)
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: rules tell you what to exclude (default is index everything), contexts to give labels (use match patterns)
#balisage2022

subs.text:
JT: Stemming using own implementation of Porter2 plus "diacritic" stemmer and "identity" stemmer, can also use your own (XSLT + JavaScript); in config
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: Stemming using own implementation of Porter2 plus "diacritic" stemmer and "identity" stemmer, can also use your own (XSLT + JavaScript); in config
#balisage2022

subs.text:
JT: Create "inverted index" JSON files, per stem gets instances; fetched one by one by JavaScript in search
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: Create "inverted index" JSON files, per stem gets instances; fetched one by one by JavaScript in search
#balisage2022

subs.text:
JT: Create other additional information during indexing: list of titles, list of all (unstemmed) words (used for wildcarding via regex)
#ballisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: Create other additional information during indexing: list of titles, list of all (unstemmed) words (used for wildcarding via regex)
#ballisage2022

subs.text:
JT: Filters and controls generated during indexing; can be used to build the search page
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: Filters and controls generated during indexing; can be used to build the search page
#balisage2022

subs.text:
JT: Considerations
Limiting factor is titles (e.g. 170K pages project => 15MB titles file)
No easy way to show matches in document
Context-specific searches, no conditional logic for filters
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: Considerations
Limiting factor is titles (e.g. 170K pages project => 15MB titles file)
No easy way to show matches in document
Context-specific searches, no conditional logic for filters
#balisage2022

subs.text:
JT: Solution for context-specific search is separate search pages over different parts (plus more generic for whole site)
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
JT: Solution for context-specific search is separate search pages over different parts (plus more generic for whole site)
#balisage2022

subs.text:
JT: Lots of stem files feels wrong, but seems to work OK

subs.text:
BTW: iXML 1.0
What's it for? 
"What if you could see everything as XML?"
Recognizing abstractions: these things are "the same"
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
BTW: iXML 1.0
What's it for? 
"What if you could see everything as XML?"
Recognizing abstractions: these things are "the same"
#balisage2022

subs.text:
BTW: But also need to understand abstractions in context, which changes their interpretation
Abstractions in context = seeing things as XML
Make this visible to the computer
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
BTW: But also need to understand abstractions in context, which changes their interpretation
Abstractions in context = seeing things as XML
Make this visible to the computer
#balisage2022

subs.text:
BTW: How does iXML work?
iXML grammar => parse input stream => XML
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
BTW: How does iXML work?
iXML grammar => parse input stream => XML
#balisage2022

subs.text:
SB: What's next?
Extend infrastructure
Encourage new iXML projects
Engage with iXML users
Evolve next iXML version: look for use cases and figure how to integrate that in language

Welcome to join group, sign up at W3C

subs.text:
EBB: Machine-assisted collation; here the various publications of Mary Shelley's Frankenstein
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
EBB: Machine-assisted collation; here the various publications of Mary Shelley's Frankenstein
#balisage2022

subs.text:
EBB: Gothenburg model of computer-aided collation
1. Tokenization (Smallest unit of comparison)
2. Normalization (e.g. & = and)
3. Alignment (chunking, identifiable start/end pts)]
4. Analysis
5. Visualization
Iterate
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
EBB: Gothenburg model of computer-aided collation
1. Tokenization (Smallest unit of comparison)
2. Normalization (e.g. & = and)
3. Alignment (chunking, identifiable start/end pts)]
4. Analysis
5. Visualization
Iterate
#balisage2022

subs.text:
EBB: Metaphor: collation as weaving
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
EBB: Metaphor: collation as weaving
#balisage2022

subs.text:
EBB: Tokenization; we need to be able to intervene in tokenization and normalization as part of our scholarship
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
EBB: Tokenization; we need to be able to intervene in tokenization and normalization as part of our scholarship
#balisage2022

subs.text:
EBB: When to make interventions? Pre- vs Post-?
Pre-processing better, but can go overboard and make new problems
Post-processing with XSLT? Yes, with care
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
EBB: When to make interventions? Pre- vs Post-?
Pre-processing better, but can go overboard and make new problems
Post-processing with XSLT? Yes, with care
#balisage2022

subs.text:
EBB: Tokenization and alignment is a research method
More than one way to do it
So scholars/programmers: share your algorithms
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
EBB: Tokenization and alignment is a research method
More than one way to do it
So scholars/programmers: share your algorithms
#balisage2022

subs.text:
EBB: Error correction is cyclical and hard
Need to document errors and interventions
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
EBB: Error correction is cyclical and hard
Need to document errors and interventions
#balisage2022

subs.text:
EBB: Machine-assisted processes need a lot of documentation
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
EBB: Machine-assisted processes need a lot of documentation
#balisage2022

subs.text:
Excuse for shout-out to my talk later in the week (Metadata for Creators), which is all about instrumentation of processes subject to a lot of cyclical tweakage
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:

subs.text:
Usdin: The world is not consisent, and we need to make markup conform to the world as it is...
#balisage2022
subs.rawText:
Usdin: The world is not consisent, and we need to make markup conform to the world as it is...
#balisage2022

subs.text:
Usdin: I believe in general consistency is desirable, except when it would be surprising.
